guide.introduction: This project is a collaboration with Jimmie Rodgers. Build a pulse-sensing headband that flashes a heart-shaped LED display to the beating of your heart! Uses a scratch-built perf board Arduino built from Mintduino parts, the Open Heart LED display, Yury and Joel's pulse sensor, and a rechargeable lithium battery and power board. The circuit is built into a brocade headband with elastic at the back.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This project is a collaboration with Jimmie Rodgers. Build a pulse-sensing headband that flashes a heart-shaped LED display to the beating of your heart! Uses a scratch-built perf board Arduino built from Mintduino parts, the Open Heart LED display, Yury and Joel's pulse sensor, and a rechargeable lithium battery and power board. The circuit is built into a brocade headband with elastic at the back.

Relevant parts
  • Mintronics: MintDuino
  • Open Heart LED Display Kit
  • Perfboard
  • Brocade ribbon
  • Elastic cord
  • Pulse Sensor
Tools
  • PanaVise
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire cutter/stripper

parts.notes: or components to build your own

lines.text: Gather materials and tools.
lines.text_raw: Gather materials and tools.

lines.text: Download the necessary Arduino code for the heartbeat headband.
lines.text_raw: Download the necessary [http://cdn.makezine.com/make/2011/12/heartbeatheadband.zip|Arduino code for the heartbeat headband].

lines.text: Assemble the Open Heart display.
lines.text_raw: Assemble the Open Heart display.

lines.text: Further instructions on the Open Heart documentation page
lines.text_raw: Further instructions on the [http://jimmieprodgers.com/kits/openheart/makeheart/|Open Heart documentation page]

lines.text: Build the Mintduino circuit on the enclosed solderless breadboard to start out, and fire up the Open Heart test code.
lines.text_raw: Build the Mintduino circuit on the enclosed solderless breadboard to start out, and fire up the Open Heart test code.

lines.text: Add the pulse sensor, load the headband's Arduino sketch onto the microcontroller, and test the sensor.
lines.text_raw: Add the pulse sensor, load the headband's Arduino sketch onto the microcontroller, and test the sensor.

lines.text: Be sure not to pinch the connectors on the back of the sensor's circuit board, just touch the side with the heart.
lines.text_raw: Be sure not to pinch the connectors on the back of the sensor's circuit board, just touch the side with the heart.

lines.text: Dry fit the components onto a piece of perfboard.
lines.text_raw: Dry fit the components onto a piece of perfboard.

lines.text: Fit the heart display over the components, and mark the component layout with a marker.
lines.text_raw: Fit the heart display over the components, and mark the component layout with a marker.

lines.text: Trim the circuit board to fit behind the heart display with a pair of shears.
lines.text_raw: Trim the circuit board to fit behind the heart display with a pair of shears.

lines.text: Double check the fit by pairing the board with the display.
lines.text_raw: Double check the fit by pairing the board with the display.

lines.text: File the edges of the fiberglass perfboard to be smooth.
lines.text_raw: File the edges of the fiberglass perfboard to be smooth.

lines.text: Wear a dusk mask!
lines.text_raw: Wear a dusk mask!

lines.text: Solder up the components of the perfboard Arduino, using component leads and small bits of wire to make connections as necessary.
lines.text_raw: Solder up the components of the perfboard Arduino, using component leads and small bits of wire to make connections as necessary.

lines.text: Headband time! Measure around the circumference of your head, then cut two pieces of ribbon to that length.
lines.text_raw: Headband time! Measure around the circumference of your head, then cut two pieces of ribbon to that length.

lines.text: Thanks to Britex Fabrics for supplying the beautiful brocade and grosgrain ribbon for this project!
lines.text_raw: Thanks to [http://www.britexfabrics.com/|Britex Fabrics] for supplying the beautiful brocade and grosgrain ribbon for this project!

lines.text: Cut a piece of cord elastic about six inches long.
lines.text_raw: Cut a piece of cord elastic about six inches long.

lines.text: Tie the ends together in a square knot to make a loop of elastic.
lines.text_raw: Tie the ends together in a square knot to make a loop of elastic.

lines.text: Line up the ribbons and use a zigzag stitch along the sides, but only sew together the ends of the ribbons, leaving the middle section open as shown.
lines.text_raw: Line up the ribbons and use a zigzag stitch along the sides, but only sew together the ends of the ribbons, leaving the middle section open as shown.

lines.text: We'll connect the ends of the ribbon with the elastic to form the headband.
lines.text_raw: We'll connect the ends of the ribbon with the elastic to form the headband.

lines.text: Fold and pin the ribbon ends to enclose the raw edge, and sandwich one side of the elastic loop in the fold.
lines.text_raw: Fold and pin the ribbon ends to enclose the raw edge, and sandwich one side of the elastic loop in the fold.

lines.text: Use this seam to hide the knot in the elastic.
lines.text_raw: Use this seam to hide the knot in the elastic.

lines.text: Stitch the ribbon seam around the elastic and repeat on the other side.
lines.text_raw: Stitch the ribbon seam around the elastic and repeat on the other side.

lines.text: Now the headband is stretchy where it needs to be, and firm everywhere else to support the (non-stretchy) circuit!
lines.text_raw: Now the headband is stretchy where it needs to be, and firm everywhere else to support the (non-stretchy) circuit!

lines.text: Wire up the sensor and power board and lay the circuit out on the headband to decide where the display will go.
lines.text_raw: Wire up the sensor and power board and lay the circuit out on the headband to decide where the display will go.

lines.text: When you find the spot you like, pierce the heart display's header pins through the outer ribbon of the headband and then through the perfboard. Solder it up.
lines.text_raw: When you find the spot you like, pierce the heart display's header pins through the outer ribbon of the headband and then through the perfboard. Solder it up.

lines.text: Stitch the power board in place, keeping in mind where the tiny lithium battery will go.
lines.text_raw: Stitch the power board in place, keeping in mind where the tiny lithium battery will go.

lines.text: Run the sensor out a small opening near the back of the headband, so it can loop around and clip to the ear.
lines.text_raw: Run the sensor out a small opening near the back of the headband, so it can loop around and clip to the ear.

lines.text: Stitch down the wires so they stay put inside the headband.
lines.text_raw: Stitch down the wires so they stay put inside the headband.

lines.text: Use a zigzag stitch to sew the headband shut along the remaining open edges.
lines.text_raw: Use a zigzag stitch to sew the headband shut along the remaining open edges.

lines.text: You may have to hand-stitch some spots too tight to get at with the sewing machine.
lines.text_raw: You may have to hand-stitch some spots too tight to get at with the sewing machine.

lines.text: Leave an opening near the power board for toggling the power and changing the battery.
lines.text_raw: Leave an opening near the power board for toggling the power and changing the battery.

lines.text: I used snaps to make a recloseable opening so I can show off the circuit.
lines.text_raw: I used snaps to make a recloseable opening so I can show off the circuit.

lines.text: Install the battery and turn it on.
lines.text_raw: Install the battery and turn it on.

lines.text: Attach the ear clip to the pulse sensor and try it on!
lines.text_raw: Attach the ear clip to the pulse sensor and try it on!

lines.text: Clip the sensor to your earlobe.
lines.text_raw: Clip the sensor to your earlobe.

lines.text: Congratulations, you're done!
lines.text_raw: Congratulations, you're done!
